Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Thermally Stable, Flexible Substrates for Flat Panel Displays
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will establish the feasibility of producing a flexible, highly transparent polyimide film that is thermally stable, has a high glass transition, displays near zero birefringence and a low coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE). This material is designed for use as a flexible flat panel display substrate. No available material displays all of these properties. The key technical problem will be the design of a molecular architecture that balances low film birefringence, which generally requires a flexible polymer, and CTE, which generally requires a rigid polymer. This apparent paradox will be addressed through the preparation of a rigid copolymer that contains both positive and negative birefringent units. The ratio of these units will be varied to obtain zero birefringence in a film of the material. Since solution casting of the rigid copolymer will result in isotropic, in-plane chain orientation, these copolymer films should display low CTEs as well as low birefringences. Structure property relationships between the polymer architecture and the film properties will be developed. This will further the scientific understanding of the interplay between molecular architecture and material properties.

The broader/commercial impact of this project includes enhanced scientific and technological understanding of these new materials which will enable the next generation of display technologies which includes flexible liquid crystal (LC) displays. Currently the LC display market alone is a hundred-billion dollar a year industry. Flexible displays would consume a large fraction of that market as well as open-up new markets for portable flexible displays. These include conformable displays that can be integrated onto clothing, flexible e-paper and e-book displays, displays for smartcards, and a host of other new applications. These new devices would dramatically impact daily life, by decreasing the cost and increasing accessibility and portability of streaming information. Current flexible substrates are either non-transparent, and so are limited to reflection mode displays, or have low processing temperatures which dramatically restricts their performance as well as number and range of display applications. If successful, the substrates to be developed under this project is expected to enable, for the first time, high temperature processing of flexible LC displays, opening the potential of new display devices of higher performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The organic light emitting diode display market grew to about $1.25 billion in 2010 and is expected to reach $2.2 billion in 2014. This growth in the display market is mainly driven by the penetration of organic light emitting diode panels into mobile phone main displays. The size and growth of the organic light emitting diode lighting market is expected to be similar and is being driven by increased efficiency over current fluorescence lighting systems.  U.S. consumers would save roughly $35 billion in power consumption each year, if adoption of organic light emitting diode lighting systems is accelerated by even a single year faster than predicted and proportionately more for every additional year adoption is accelerated. To increase these devices’ robustness, reduce their weight, and increase their flexibility, it is desirable to replace the front glass pane with a plastic film.  To do this, a plastic resin that can be cast into a film that is highly transparent, can be processed at high temperatures, and is very dimensionally stable with respect to temperature is needed.  There are materials available that display some of the targeted properties and they have been utilized to fabricate prototype thin, light-weight displays and lighting systems.  None of these devices are currently commercially available due to their low performance and production yields. The commercialization of these device would be greatly facilitated if the processing temperatures could be increased, which would increase the device performance, efficiency and durability. The processing temperatures are limited by the lack of a material that possesses all the targeted properties listed above. Such a material could help enable the production of flexible and conformable displays and lighting systems, opening the door to many new applications that are widely sought after by both industrial and military concerns.

 This project has resulted in the development of a new resin that can be cast into a film with all the required properties for the applications discussed above.  The material developed by this project expands our understanding of molecular design in materials science and will expand the utilization of organic light emitting diodes in devices by improving device electrical efficiency and the consumer experienced robustness. In addition to the standard organic light emitting diode display market, this substrate will enable the development of the flexible display market. These technologies will be used for conformable displays that can be integrated onto clothing, flexible e-paper and e-book displays, displays for smartcards, and a host of other new applications. These new devices will dramatically impact daily life, by decreasing the cost and increasing accessibility and portability of information.

To support commercialization and market entry, a number of commercialization partners have been identified and contacted. Negotiations with these partners are ongoing. A number of potential customers including display, lighting, and sensor manufactures have been contacted.  These customers have been sent samples of the developed resin for their evaluation.  Feedback has been positive, and modifications are being made to the resin to tailor it for specific applications.  Sales of the resin will result in significant job creation at APS and its commercialization partners.
